籤詩版本二:
Like a crane emerging from its mortal cage
Get rid of the mortal cage and have a clear path
No barriers between north, south, east and west
Let me go straight to Jiuxiao Palace
詩意: This hexagram represents the image of a crane leaving its cage. Everything is bad in advance and good in the end.
解曰: No worries. The road is prosperous. Be at ease. Carefree as a human (god).
籤詩故事一:
◇Ziya abandoned his official position
When Jiang Ziya was working as a fortune teller, he saw that a woman had been transformed by the jade pipa spirit, so he grabbed her and even beat her with an inkstone. King Zhou's prime minister explained what had happened, asked what had happened, and then took Jiang Ziya to see King Zhou. Jiang Ziya used Samadhi True Fire to burn the pipa spirit out of its original shape in front of King Zhou, and King Zhou made him a senior official.
In order to avenge the jade pipa spirit, Daji asked King Zhou to order Jiang Ziya to build a deer platform. Jiang Ziya rebuked King Zhou, and King Zhou ordered him to be killed. Jiang Ziya escaped by using water. After returning home, Jiang Ziya asked Ma about going to Xiqi, and Ma wanted to divorce him. So Jiang Ziya went to Xiqi (the capital of King Wen of Zhou Dynasty) alone.
Jiang Ziya arrived in Xiqi and lived in seclusion fishing in Panxi Gorge. He met King Wen of Zhou who was eager to seek talents. At King Wen's sincere request, Jiang Ziya was worshiped as his teacher and assisted King Wen.
聖意:
The house is uneasy.
Oneself returns one's wishes.
Seek financial cooperation.
Transaction.
Marriage.
Rokko Male.
Pedestrians: See you.
Tiancan Qiuli.


Six animals are damaged.
Looking for people to hinder.
Public litigation should be peaceful.
Migration is lucky.
Lost property Southeast.
Diseases are provided.
Mountain tomb is auspicious.
